text: 50 Years in PEAD Research Marek Sojka, PhD Bonum Quant Research Oxford, United Kingdom 25th November 2018 Abstract Analysing earning’s predictive power on stock returns was in the heart of academic research since late 60’s. First introduced to academic world in 1967 during seminar “Analysis of Security Prices” by Chicago University Professors Ray Ball and Philip Brown. In the next four decades was extensively analysed by many academics and is now a well-documented anomaly and is referred to as Post Earnings Announcement Drift (PEAD). This phenomenon is still at the centre of academic research because it stands at odds with efficient market hypothesis which assumes that all information is instantaneously reflected in stock prices. Professional investors are also closely looking at PEAD as it implies that it is easy to beat the market average by simply ranking stocks based on their earnings surprise and investing in the top decile, quintile or quartile and shorting the bottom part. Academic evidence shows that this strategy produces an abnormal return of somewhere between 2.6% and 9.37% per quarter, according to various authors. In this paper I will present existing evidence supporting and contradicting “PEAD”, the history of academic research in that field and various techniques used to verify the phenomenon. The paper is organised as follows: first the history of the PEAD academic research is presented, in the second more recent evidence and research techniques used by authors are presented and finally conclusions and various critics of PEAD are shown. text: The first who spotted the phenomenon were Ball and Brown (1968) who were examining the meaning of net income number for investors in general. They found that about half of all the information issued by a firm during a year is captured by the income number. They assume that capital markets are efficient and therefore should adjust to any new valuable information quickly without leaving any opportunity to earn abnormal returns in subsequent periods. Based on this assumption they prove that market prices adjust according to announced net income numbers in line with magnitude of increase/decrease in net income. In their research they looked for the amount of new information conveyed by the income number, so they divided the income number to two parts: the expected part and unexpected part. Investors should react to the unexpected income part and adjust the stock price accordingly but should not react to part of income that was expected. Their research was focused on annual income numbers, they concluded that over half of all the individual information regarding a company is included in income number and that 85%- 90% of the content of the annual income number is captured by other media, most notably quarterly earnings reports. The value of information conveyed by annual income numbers is only about 20% of the value of all information coming to the market in the month the report is released. They treat this as a proof of market efficiency, as investors turned their attention away from annual reports to other information that was more useful in analysing company’s future financial earning power. Table 1 shows how much information regarding period’s earnings is reflected in stock prices in the year of announcement which supports their hypothesis of usefulness of income numbers, but the more intriguing fact was that stock prices drifted in the direction of earnings for another 6 months after annual report announcement. This phenomenon was left unanswered and for further academic research. Since their discovery, there were many academic research efforts (described below) that proved beyond doubt exitance of stock price drift after earnings announcement. Fama (1998) himself a proponent of efficient market hypothesis acknowledged that the existence of the Post Earnings Announcement Drift is beyond suspicion and as he states: “has survived robustness checks and extension to more recent data.” Lev and Ohlson (1982) describe the evidence of PEAD as: “the most damaging to the naïve and unwavering belief in market efficiency”. 2 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3281679

Jones and Litzenberger (1970) conducted an empirical test to find if investors indeed do not price the unexpected earnings immediately after announcement. They calculated the expected quarterly earnings level based on a linear regression model for 8 consecutive quarters prior to earnings announcement. They looked at the performance of those stocks in years 1962-1967. Their definition of unexpected earnings was defined as more than 1.5 standard deviations apart from the expected level. They observed only performance of the stocks that met that definition and used a six-month holding period return starting at the end of the tenth quarter, because it was the month when most companies reported their earnings. The authors found that 211 stocks that beat their expected earnings by more than 1.5 standard deviations in the observed period returned on average 17.5% over the subsequent 6 months period comparing to 5.3% for the S&P Index. They also pointed to the fact that the average beta in their portfolio was 1.4 and the risk adjusted return was 10.7%. On the other side, they found that the performance of the group of stocks that announced earnings more than 1.5 standard deviations below expectations did not differ from the index performance. In his article, Brown contemplates various explanations for observed price drift. He looks into research details of the academic research and points to information processing cost, transaction costs and research design flaws as suspected explanations. He finds that previous research used flawed assumption about the announcement day, assuming that all the profits are available at the end of the second or third month of the next quarter, as detailed evidence suggests This assumption is not true and may seriously impede test results, because some of the positive earnings surprises may be included before their official announcement which off course falsely overstates the PEAD. That assumption was made by Jones and Litzenberger (1970), Litzenberger, Joy and Jones (1971), Latane, Jones and Rieke (1974), Basu (1977) and Watts (1978). However, Ball (1978) states that this bias is small compared to observed excess returns. Information processing cost and transaction costs are also rejected as possible explanations because they may explain the sign but cannot explain the magnitude of observed excess returns. His other considered biases include the possibility that an omitted risk metric is correlated with change in earnings, or that used methods to estimate risk are flawed, and the estimation error is correlated with earnings. Those suspicions are impossible to confirm or reject, but assuming they are right would undermine market equilibrium model. Ball (1978) concludes: “The most important results of this study are the findings relative to market efficiency. The excess returns from purchasing the qualifying securities at the time of publication of the EPS number substantially exceed transaction costs. The adjustment process, rather than being instantaneous, is lengthy (about 45 market days). Thus, with respect to this particular sample of securities, the market exhibited inefficiencies” A differing explanation of observed abnormal returns after quarterly earnings surprise was offered by Watts (1978), he proves that the observed significant abnormal returns are not enough to cover transaction costs, unless an investor can trade at substantially lower costs (market makers, banks, brokers, professional investors). He points at the transaction costs as the decisive factor for existing abnormal returns, he also states that it is not possible that they exist due to deficiency in the capital asset-pricing model, as suggested by Ball (1978). They proved that their results are statistically significant using a t-statistic and show that even the Reinganum’s (1981) period has statistically significant abnormal returns for portfolios +1 month to +3 months, but they also notice that the portfolios +4 and +5 month in Reinganum’s period are in fact the only two in the sample that are not statistically significant. They looked into price behaviour 20 days prior the announcement day up to 90 days after the earnings announcement using the same SUE definition. What is also interesting is that magnitude of positive earnings surprise relates with abnormal return, on the negative side, the magnitude of the SUE does not matter, it is the inclusion in the last three deciles that is decisive.
